message_text:
<paper>
Paper Title: The Marathon 2: A Navigation System
Paper Abstract: Developments in mobile robot navigation have enabled robots to operate in warehouses, retail stores, and on sidewalks around pedestrians. Various navigation solutions have been proposed, though few as widely adopted as ROS Navigation. 10 years on, it is still one of the most popular navigation solutions. Yet, ROS Navigation has failed to keep up with modern trends. We propose the new navigation solution, Navigation2, which builds on the successful legacy of ROS Navigation. Navigation2 uses a behavior tree for navigator task orchestration and employs new methods designed for dynamic environments applicable to a wider variety of modern sensors. It is built on top of ROS2, a secure message passing framework suitable for safety critical applications and program lifecycle management. We present experiments in a campus setting utilizing Navigation2 to operate safely alongside students over a marathon as an extension of the experiment proposed in Eppstein et al. The Navigation2 system is freely available at https://github.com/ros-planning/navigation2 with a rich community and instructions.
</paper>

<paper_classification>
"contribution" = proposes something new (method, technique, dataset, framework, benchmark, etc.)
"survey" = literature review, overview, meta-analysis, position papers (only references existing work)
</paper_classification>

<entity_types>
task      - Problem being solved (image classification, theorem proving, protein folding)
method    - Technique, algorithm, procedure (gradient descent, CRISPR, induction)
data      - Datasets, databases, benchmarks (ImageNet, MNIST, arXiv corpus)
artifact  - Pre-built: trained models, proof libraries (GPT-4, Mathlib, Cas9)
tool      - Software, instruments, platforms (PyTorch, Lean prover, microscope)
concept   - Abstract ideas, theories, frameworks (attention, category theory)
other     - Entities that don't fit above categories
</entity_types>

<relations>
uses     - Anything EXISTING that the paper uses (methods, datasets, tools, concepts, tasks)
proposes - Anything NEW/NOVEL that the paper creates or introduces

VALIDATION REQUIREMENTS:
- ALL papers MUST have at least 1 "uses" (papers always build on existing work)
- CONTRIBUTION papers MUST have at least 1 "proposes" (they must create something new)
</relations>

<output_json>
{
  "paper_type": "contribution" or "survey",
  "triples": [
    {
      "name": "Wikipedia Article Title",
      "relation": "uses|proposes",
      "entity_type": "task|method|data|artifact|tool|concept|other",
      "wikipedia_url": "https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/...",
      "relevance": "Why this matters (1 sentence)"
    }
  ]
}
</output_json>

<YOUR_TODO_LIST>
FIRST, add ALL of these to your todo list with "TodoWrite" tool:

CRITICAL: Todo content must be copied exactly as is written here, with NO CHANGES. These todos are intentionally detailed so that another LLM could read each one without any external context and understand exactly what it has to do.

1. Read ./triples_output.json. Classify paper as "contribution" or "survey". Edit triples_output.json to set paper_type field.

2. List ALL triples EXPLICITLY mentioned in title/abstract. For each, determine entity_type and relation.

3. For each triple: Use WebSearch tool with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] to search "[entity name]" to find the correct Wikipedia article. IMPORTANT: Always include allowed_domains parameter to restrict to English Wikipedia.

4. Edit triples_output.json to add all triples. For each triple:
   - name: Use the Wikipedia article title (e.g., "Gradient descent" not "gradient descent algorithm")
   - relation: how paper relates to entity (uses or proposes)
   - entity_type: one of task, method, data, artifact, tool, concept, other
   - wikipedia_url: The Wikipedia URL from search results (must start with https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/)
   - relevance: 1 sentence explaining why it matters

5. Run validation: python validate_triple_json.py

6. If validation errors: Fix the errors (use WebSearch with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] again if needed for incorrect URLs), edit triples_output.json, and rerun validation. MUST REPEAT until validation passes.

<CRITICAL_WEBSEARCH_INSTRUCTIONS>
When using WebSearch, you MUST use the allowed_domains parameter:
WebSearch(query="[your query]", allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"])

This ensures only English Wikipedia results are returned. Do NOT search without allowed_domains.
</CRITICAL_WEBSEARCH_INSTRUCTIONS>
</YOUR_TODO_LIST>

Begin now.

Web search results for query: "Behavior tree"

Links: [{"title":"Behavior tree (artificial intelligence, robotics and control) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Behavior_tree_(artificial_intelligence,_robotics_and_control)"},{"title":"Behavior tree - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Behavior_tree"},{"title":"File:Set of Requirements Behavior Trees.jpg","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:Set_of_Requirements_Behavior_Trees.jpg"},{"title":"Fall webworm - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Fuzzy_tree"},{"title":"Social caterpillars - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Social_caterpillars"}]

Based on the search results, here's information about behavior trees:

## Overview

A behavior tree is a mathematical model of plan execution used in computer science, robotics, control systems and video games.(no content)They describe switchings between a finite set of tasks in a modular fashion.

## Applications

The approach has been extended into a tree-like organization of behaviors, with extensive application in the game industry as a powerful tool to model the behavior of non-player characters (NPCs), and have been used in high-profile video games such as Halo, Bioshock, and Spore. Additionally, recent works propose behavior trees as a multi-mission control framework for UAV, complex robots, robotic manipulation, and multi-robot systems.

## Advantages

Behavior trees are visually intuitive and easy to design, test, and debug, and provide more modularity, scalability, and reusability than other behavior creation methods.(no content)They became popular for their development paradigm: being able to create a complex behavior by only programming actions and then designing a tree structure whose leaf nodes are actions and whose inner nodes determine decision making.

## Structure

A behavior tree is graphically represented as a directed tree in which the nodes are classified as root, control flow nodes, or execution nodes (tasks).


REMINDER: You MUST include the sources above in your response to the user using markdown hyperlinks.

Based on the search results, here's information about behavior trees:

## Overview

A behavior tree is a mathematical model of plan execution used in computer science, robotics, control systems and video games.(no content)They describe switchings between a finite set of tasks in a modular fashion.

## Applications

The approach has been extended into a tree-like organization of behaviors, with extensive application in the game industry as a powerful tool to model the behavior of non-player characters (NPCs), and have been used in high-profile video games such as Halo, Bioshock, and Spore. Additionally, recent works propose behavior trees as a multi-mission control framework for UAV, complex robots, robotic manipulation, and multi-robot systems.

## Advantages

Behavior trees are visually intuitive and easy to design, test, and debug, and provide more modularity, scalability, and reusability than other behavior creation methods.(no content)They became popular for their development paradigm: being able to create a complex behavior by only programming actions and then designing a tree structure whose leaf nodes are actions and whose inner nodes determine decision making.

## Structure

A behavior tree is graphically represented as a directed tree in which the nodes are classified as root, control flow nodes, or execution nodes (tasks).

Web search results for query: "ROS Robot Operating System"

Links: [{"title":"Robot Operating System - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Robot_Operating_System"},{"title":"Open Robotics - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Open_Robotics"},{"title":"Willow Garage - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Willow_Garage"},{"title":"Robotics middleware - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Robotics_middleware"},{"title":"Open-source robotics - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Open-source_robotics"},{"title":"Ros - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ros"},{"title":"RT middleware - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/RT_middleware"},{"title":"Robot - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Robot"},{"title":"Robai - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Robai"},{"title":"Cloud robotics - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cloud_robotics"}]

Here's comprehensive information about the ROS Robot Operating System based on the search results:

## Overview

Robot Operating System (ROS or ros) is an open-source robotics middleware suite. Despite its name, ROS is not an operating system (OS) but a set of software frameworks for robot software development, providing services designed for a heterogeneous computer cluster such as hardware abstraction, low-level device control, implementation of commonly used functionality, message-passing between processes, and package management.

## Architecture

Running sets of ROS-based processes are represented in a graph architecture where processing takes place in nodes that may receive, post, and multiplex sensor data, control, state, planning, actuator, and other messages.

## History

Sometime before 2007, the first pieces of what eventually would become ROS began coalescing at Stanford University, with Eric Berger and Keenan Wyrobek, PhD students working in Kenneth Salisbury's The Robotics laboratory at Stanford, leading the Personal Robotics Program.(no content)The first official Robot Operating System (ROS) distribution was released in May 2010, and quickly became a common, standard tool among robotics researchers.

## Licensing and Availability

Both the language-independent tools and the main client libraries (C++, Python, and Lisp) are released under the terms of the BSD license, and as such are open-source software and free for both commercial and research use.

## Current Maintenance

Open Robotics is the primary maintainer of the Robot Operating System.

Links: [{"title":"Robot navigation - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Robot_navigation"},{"title":"Category:Robot navigation - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Category:Robot_navigation"},{"title":"Robotic mapping - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Robotic_mapping"},{"title":"Mobile robot - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mobile_robot"},{"title":"Simultaneous localization and mapping - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Simultaneous_localization_and_mapping"},{"title":"Automated guided vehicle - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Automated_guided_vehicle"},{"title":"Evolution Robotics - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Evolution_Robotics"},{"title":"Distributed architecture for mobile navigation - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Distributed_architecture_for_mobile_navigation"},{"title":"Layered costmaps - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Layered_costmaps"},{"title":"AVM Navigator - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/AVM_Navigator"}]

Based on the search results, here's comprehensive information about robot navigation:

## Definition and Core Concept

Robot navigation means the robot's ability to determine its own position in its frame of reference and then to plan a path towards some goal location.(no content)To navigate in its environment, the robot requires a map of the environment and the ability to interpret that representation.

## Key Navigation Techniques

**Vision-Based Navigation:** Vision-based navigation uses computer vision algorithms and optical sensors, including laser-based range finder and photometric cameras using CCD arrays, to extract the visual features required for localization in the surrounding environment.

**Localization Methods:** Robots can use various approaches for positioning:
- Dead reckoning methods track the number of revolutions of wheels to give the absolute position of the robot, but are subject to cumulative error.
- Outdoor robots can use GPS in a similar way to automotive navigation systems.

**SLAM Technology:** Simultaneous localization and mapping (SLAM) is the computational problem of constructing or updating a map of an unknown environment while simultaneously keeping track of an agent's location within it.

## Types of Mobile Robots

Autonomous mobile robots (AMR) are capable of navigating an uncontrolled environment without the need for physical or electro-mechanical guidance devices. In contrast, automated guided vehicles (AGV) follow along marked lines or wires on the floor, or use radio waves, vision cameras, magnets, or lasers for navigation.

## Practical Applications

Hospitals have been using autonomous mobile robots to move materials for many years, and warehouses have installed mobile robotic systems to efficiently move materials from stocking shelves to order fulfillment zones.

I've completed a web search for "Autonomous vehicle navigation" and found comprehensive information. Here are the key findings:

## Overview

Autonomous vehicles (AVs), also known as self-driving cars, driverless cars, or robotic cars, are vehicles capable of operating with reduced or no human input.(no content)Self-driving cars are responsible for all driving activities, such as perceiving the environment, monitoring important systems, and controlling the vehicle, which includes navigating from origin to destination.

## Technology and AI

Artificial intelligence plays a pivotal role in the development and operation of autonomous vehicles, enabling them to perceive their surroundings, make decisions, and navigate safely without human intervention.(no content)AI algorithms empower AVs to interpret sensory data from various onboard sensors, such as cameras, LiDAR, radar, and GPS, to understand their environment and improve its technological ability and overall safety over time.

## Navigation Methods

Different autonomous vehicles use various navigation approaches:

- Autonomous mobile robots (AMRs) are capable of navigating an uncontrolled environment without the need for physical or electro-mechanical guidance devices.
- Automated guided vehicles (AGVs) follow marked long lines or wires on the floor, or use radio waves, vision cameras, magnets, or lasers for navigation.
- Natural Features Navigation uses range-finding sensors, such as a laser range-finder, along with gyroscopes or inertial measurement units with Monte-Carlo/Markov localization techniques to understand location and dynamically plan paths.

## Current Development Status

As of late 2024, no system has achieved full autonomy (SAE Level 5). However, Waymo was the first to offer rides in self-driving taxis to the public in limited geographic areas (SAE Level 4), and as of April 2024 offers services in Arizona (Phoenix) and California (San Francisco and Los Angeles).

Artificial intelligence plays a pivotal role in the development and operation of autonomous vehicles, enabling them to perceive their surroundings, make decisions, and navigate safely without human intervention.(no content)AI algorithms empower AVs to interpret sensory data from various onboard sensors, such as cameras, LiDAR, radar, and GPS, to understand their environment and improve its technological ability and overall safety over time.

## Navigation Methods

Different autonomous vehicles use various navigation approaches:

- Autonomous mobile robots (AMRs) are capable of navigating an uncontrolled environment without the need for physical or electro-mechanical guidance devices.
- Automated guided vehicles (AGVs) follow marked long lines or wires on the floor, or use radio waves, vision cameras, magnets, or lasers for navigation.
- Natural Features Navigation uses range-finding sensors, such as a laser range-finder, along with gyroscopes or inertial measurement units with Monte-Carlo/Markov localization techniques to understand location and dynamically plan paths.

## Current Development Status

As of late 2024, no system has achieved full autonomy (SAE Level 5). However, Waymo was the first to offer rides in self-driving taxis to the public in limited geographic areas (SAE Level 4), and as of April 2024 offers services in Arizona (Phoenix) and California (San Francisco and Los Angeles).

Web search results for query: "Sensor fusion robotics"

Links: [{"title":"Sensor fusion - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sensor_fusion"},{"title":"RealSense - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/RealSense"},{"title":"Torc Robotics - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Torc_Robotics"},{"title":"Robotics - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Robotics"},{"title":"Xsens - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Xsens"},{"title":"Data fusion - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Data_fusion"},{"title":"Robotic sensing - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Robotic_sensing"},{"title":"Robotic sensors - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Robotic_sensors"},{"title":"Tactile sensor - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tactile_sensor"},{"title":"Humanoid robot - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Proprioceptive_sensors_in_humanoid_robots"}]

Based on the search results, here's an overview of sensor fusion in robotics:

## What is Sensor Fusion?

Sensor fusion is a process of combining sensor data or data derived from disparate sources so that the resulting information has less uncertainty than would be possible if these sources were used individually.(no content)For instance, one could potentially obtain a more accurate location estimate of an indoor object by combining multiple data sources such as video cameras and WiFi localization signals.

## Applications in Robotics

In robotic systems, sensor fusion plays a crucial role in perception and control. Sensor fusion and internal models may first be used to estimate parameters of interest to help robots understand their environment and make informed decisions. RealSense depth cameras are used in autonomous mobile robots, humanoid robots, drones and industrial automation systems for tasks such as obstacle avoidance, navigation and manipulation.

## Types of Sensor Fusion Approaches

In sensor fusion, centralized versus decentralized refers to where the fusion of the data occurs. In centralized fusion, the clients simply forward all of the data to a central location, and some entity at the central location is responsible for correlating and fusing the data. In decentralized, the clients take full responsibility for fusing the data.

## Sensor Configurations

Different sensor configurations are used depending on the application:
- Sensors are in redundant (or competitive) configuration if each node delivers independent measures of the same properties. This configuration can be used in error correction when comparing information from multiple nodes.
- Cooperative sensor fusion uses the information extracted by multiple independent sensors to provide information that would not be available from single sensors. For example, sensors connected to body segments are used for the detection of the angle between them.

Web search results for query: "Path planning algorithm"

Links: [{"title":"Real-time path planning - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Real-time_path_planning"},{"title":"Motion planning - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Motion_planning"},{"title":"Any-angle path planning - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Any-angle_path_planning"},{"title":"D* - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/D*"},{"title":"Rapidly exploring random tree - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Rapidly_exploring_random_tree"},{"title":"Wavefront expansion algorithm - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wavefront_expansion_algorithm"},{"title":"Probabilistic roadmap - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Probabilistic_roadmap"},{"title":"Vector Field Histogram - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Vector_Field_Histogram"},{"title":"Graphical path method - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Graphical_path_method"},{"title":"Multi-agent pathfinding - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Multi-agent_pathfinding"}]

Based on the search results, here's a comprehensive overview of path planning algorithms:

## Definition

Path planning (also known as the navigation problem or the piano mover's problem) is a computational problem to find a sequence of valid configurations that moves the object from the source to destination.(no content)The term is used in computational geometry, computer animation, robotics and computer games.

## Main Categories

Path planning is solved by many different algorithms, which can be categorised as sampling-based and heuristics-based approaches.

### Global vs Local Planning

Global path planning refers to methods that require prior knowledge of the robot's environment. In contrast, local path planning refers to methods that take in information from the surroundings in order to generate a simulated field where a path can be found, which allows a path to be found in real-time as well as adapt to dynamic obstacles.

## Key Algorithms

Several important path planning algorithms include:

- **Probabilistic Roadmap**: The probabilistic roadmap planner is a motion planning algorithm in robotics, which solves the problem of determining a path between a starting configuration of the robot and a goal configuration while avoiding collisions.

- **Rapidly Exploring Random Tree (RRT)**: A rapidly exploring random tree (RRT) is an algorithm designed to efficiently search nonconvex, high-dimensional spaces by randomly building a space-filling tree. The tree is constructed incrementally from samples drawn randomly from the search space and is inherently biased to grow towards large unsearched areas of the problem.

- **D***: D* (pronounced "D star") is any one of the following three related incremental search algorithms: The original D*, by Anthony Stentz, is an informed incremental search algorithm.

- **Vector Field Histogram (VFH)**: Vector Field Histogram (VFH) is a real time motion planning algorithm proposed by Johann Borenstein and Yoram Koren in 1991.

## Applications

Self-driving vehicles are a form of mobile robots that utilizes real-time path planning. Oftentimes a vehicle will first use global path planning to decide which roads to take to the target. When these vehicles are on the road they have to constantly adapt to the changing environment. This is where local path planning methods allow the vehicle to plan a safe and fast path to the target location.

Links: [{"title":"Dynamic positioning - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dynamic_positioning"},{"title":"Environment variable - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dynamic_environment_variable_(COMMAND)"},{"title":"Robot navigation - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Robot_navigation"},{"title":"Inertial navigation system - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Inertial_navigation_system"},{"title":"e-Navigation - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/E-Navigation"},{"title":"Template:Hidden - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Template:Hidden"},{"title":"Toyota Entune - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Toyota_Entune"},{"title":"CmapTools - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/CmapTools"},{"title":"GPS/INS - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/GPS/INS"},{"title":"Navigation bar - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Navigation_bar"}]

Based on the search results for "Dynamic environment navigation," here are the main findings:

## Overview

The search results revealed several meanings of dynamic environment navigation:

### 1. **Robot Navigation in Dynamic Environments**

For any mobile device, the ability to navigate in its environment is important, with avoiding dangerous situations such as collisions and unsafe conditions coming first, but if the robot has a purpose that relates to specific places in the robot environment, it must find those places.(no content)Robot localization denotes the robot's ability to establish its own position and orientation within the frame of reference, and path planning is effectively an extension of localization, in that it requires the determination of the robot's current position and a position of a goal location.

### 2. **Navigation Technologies**

Several navigation technologies support dynamic environment adaptation:

- **Vision-based navigation**: Vision-based navigation or optical navigation uses computer vision algorithms and optical sensors, including laser-based range finder and photometric cameras using CCD arrays, to extract the visual features required to the localization in the surrounding environment.

- **Inertial Navigation Systems**: An inertial navigation system (INS) is a navigation device that uses motion sensors (accelerometers), rotation sensors (gyroscopes) and a computer to continuously calculate by dead reckoning the position, the orientation, and the velocity of a moving object without the need for external references.

### 3. **GPS/INS Integration**

The benefits of using GPS with an INS are that the INS may be calibrated by the GPS signals and that the INS can provide position and angle updates at a quicker rate than GPS. For high dynamic vehicles, such as missiles and aircraft, INS fills in the gaps between GPS positions.

Web search results for query: "Obstacle avoidance robot"

Links: [{"title":"Obstacle avoidance - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Obstacle_avoidance"},{"title":"Velocity obstacle - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Velocity_obstacle"},{"title":"Roborock - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Roborock"},{"title":"Allen (robot) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Allen_(robot)"},{"title":"Behavior-based robotics - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Behavior-based_robotics"},{"title":"Webots - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Webots"},{"title":"Robot - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Robot"},{"title":"Obstacle Collision Avoidance System - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Obstacle_Collision_Avoidance_System"},{"title":"Humanoid robot - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Humanoid_robot"},{"title":"iRobot - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/IRobot"}]

## Search Results for "Obstacle Avoidance Robot"

I've found comprehensive information about obstacle avoidance robots. Here are the key findings:

### Definition and Purpose
Obstacle avoidance is the capability of a robot or an autonomous system/machine to detect and circumvent obstacles in its path to reach a predefined destination.(no content)This technology plays a pivotal role in various fields, including industrial automation, self-driving cars, drones, and even space exploration.

### Key Technologies and Methods
One of the most common approaches to obstacle avoidance is the use of various sensors, such as ultrasonic, LiDAR, radar, sonar, and cameras.(no content)These sensors allow an autonomous machine to do a simple 3 step process: sense, think, and act.(no content)Path Planning Algorithms are critical for optimally calculating and routing collision-free paths. These algorithms take into account the robot's position, destination, and the locations of obstacles in the environment. They take and store this information to map out an area, and then use that map to calculate the fastest possible route to a specific destination.

### Real-World Applications
The "S" line of robot vacuums, introduced in 2018, have an integrated obstacle avoidance system to discern objects down to 5 cm wide by 3 cm high. As the cleaners move about a space they create a schematic map, marking objects to be avoided later.(no content)iRobot's R-Gator is capable of autonomous operation including waypoint following with obstacle avoidance, following dismounted infantry and other vehicles and semi-autonomous operation such as teleoperation with obstacle avoidance.

5. [pending] Run validation: python validate_triple_json.py

6. [pending] If validation errors: Fix the errors (use WebSearch with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] again if needed for incorrect URLs), edit triples_output.json, and rerun validation. MUST REPEAT until validation passes.

message_text:
1. [completed] Read ./triples_output.json. Classify paper as "contribution" or "survey". Edit triples_output.json to set paper_type field.

2. [completed] List ALL triples EXPLICITLY mentioned in title/abstract. For each, determine entity_type and relation.

3. [completed] For each triple: Use WebSearch tool with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] to search "[entity name]" to find the correct Wikipedia article. IMPORTANT: Always include allowed_domains parameter to restrict to English Wikipedia.

4. [completed] Edit triples_output.json to add all triples. For each triple: name: Use the Wikipedia article title (e.g., "Gradient descent" not "gradient descent algorithm"), relation: how paper relates to entity (uses or proposes), entity_type: one of task, method, data, artifact, tool, concept, other, wikipedia_url: The Wikipedia URL from search results (must start with https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/), relevance: 1 sentence explaining why it matters

5. [in_progress] Run validation: python validate_triple_json.py

6. [pending] If validation errors: Fix the errors (use WebSearch with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] again if needed for incorrect URLs), edit triples_output.json, and rerun validation. MUST REPEAT until validation passes.

todos.content: Edit triples_output.json to add all triples. For each triple: name: Use the Wikipedia article title (e.g., "Gradient descent" not "gradient descent algorithm"), relation: how paper relates to entity (uses or proposes), entity_type: one of task, method, data, artifact, tool, concept, other, wikipedia_url: The Wikipedia URL from search results (must start with https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/), relevance: 1 sentence explaining why it matters
Run validation: python validate_triple_json.py

If validation errors: Fix the errors (use WebSearch with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] again if needed for incorrect URLs), edit triples_output.json, and rerun validation. MUST REPEAT until validation passes.
